discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think people are confused because all of the steps are valid ones to take. The key is the question asks which step to take NEXT. That means you have to fit the steps into the IR process.

We're past identification as we have a live worm spreading. Next step is containment.

A) This needs to happen, but could take a long time fo results. This is a post-incident activity.
B) Changes like this are part of remediation / recovery. But it only says it revealed the worm; not that it stopped it.
C) This would make sense, but slowness is being reported for "all workstation segments". In other words, it's hit every VLAN already.
D) Updating your IPS is the best chance you have at stopping it. You don't need much for IOC's, just anything that you're getting from the anti-malware. An EXE, a port, a signature...

comments.content: Thinking this over, I would to D. Contain the malware on each machine. This way when you clean the malware, a host doesn't get reinfected.

discussion.content:
A) This takes too long
B) The question says all work stations are slow, implying all devices are infected. 
C) The malware hit all segments, so there's nothing to contain
D) Again, the worm spread, so there's nothing to contain.

All these options are terrible lol

Selected Answer: C
C. Enable an ACL on all VLANs to contain each segment.

ChatGPT says it's C...
Well, might be a point.
"Slowness across ALL network segments" Which means the worm has already spread across all work stations. You cannot halt what has already spread. I'm going with A also

Selected Answer: D
D is correct one for NEXT action to be taken

Selected Answer: C
I went several times on this question. days have passed. i looked at everyone. all answer make sense.
The thing is they say all workstation segments. and while the word ALL is important, but also workstation. What about the rest that are NOT workstations ? servers , databases etc ? We want to contain it as it an WORM that spreads allone - think SQL Slammer https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL_Slammer . So I think the ACL - segmenting ALL segments is the best answer, closing the ports that the worm is using. It is fast and it contains it in the workstation segments that are already infected. the signature and the new anti malware could be done later the Remediation step.

Everyone keeps saying "this has hit every vlan already" as there reasoning for not choosing C.

So let me ask you this.. Do servers also live on vlan segments ... that have not potentially been affected yet?

comments.content: Yeah they're saying it's hit every network segment, but then choose D to stop the spread. It makes no sense. I'm still leaning towards C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is a more immediate response to the incident. Deploying the new anti-malware on all uninfected systems will help prevent further infections and reduce the spread of the worm. D is not an immediate response to the incident and may take some time to complete.

Both options are important, but in this specific scenario, B is the more urgent and effective next step to take.

Containment is key

comments.content: After carefully reading the question again, I am changing my answer to C. Compiling Ioc and updating IPS won't do much good because the worm is on the network already. IPS cannot prevent it because it is already present...the key is to control the spread.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The answer cannot be "B" .....but a different anti-malware product was just downloaded and has revealed a worm is spreading...the different product only revealed that worm is spreading ONLY..it did not fix anything.

Scenario: Network is slow and multiple machine is infected by worm which detected by new AV which is not yet deployed. Best to know what are the infected machine and isolate, to know this, we need to update the signature that the machine has installed already instead of installing new AV
- Deploying new anti-malware on all uninfected systems is not an answer: network is slow and we do not know which machine are not infected. 
- Enable ACL : multiple machine infected, it will not help
- Compile a list of IoC: applicable once its determine the spread of infection.

cyber incident response plan has 6 phases, 
They Have identified and next would be contain. Halt the spread. Answer is D
 Preparation,
 Identification, 
Containment, 
Eradication,
 Recovery and
 Lessons Learned

questions.question_text: The SOC has received reports of slowness across all workstation network segments. The currently installed antivirus has not detected anything, but a different anti-malware product was just downloaded and has revealed a worm is spreading. Which of the following should be the NEXT step in this incident response?

choices.B: Begin deploying the new anti-malware on all uninfected systems.
choices.D: Compile a list of IoCs so the IPS can be updated to halt the spread.
choices.C: Enable an ACL on all VLANs to contain each segment.
choices.A: Send a sample of the malware to the antivirus vendor and request urgent signature creation.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
https://dmarcian.com/spf-syntax-table/

https://dmarcian.com/spf-syntax-table/ - C

Selected Answer: C
An SPF soft fail is a status result that means that the senders IP address is probably not authorized

questions.question_text: An analyst is reviewing email headers to determine if an email has been sent from a legitimate sender. The organization uses SPF to validate email origination. Which of the following most likely indicates an invalid originator?
Which of the following SCAP standards provides standardization for measuring and describing the severity of security-related software flaws?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The definition comes straight from Mike Chapple's/David Seidl's book for CVSS
"Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Provides a standardized approach for measuring and describing the severity of security-related software flaws"

I'd go B.

"CVSS is the overall score assigned to a vulnerability. CVE is simply a list of all publicly disclosed vulnerabilities that includes the CVE ID, a description, dates, and comments. The CVSS score is not reported in the CVE listing â you must use the NVD to find assigned CVSS scores."

Selected Answer: B
CVSS provides aa standardized approach for measuring and describing the severity of security- related software flaws.

questions.question_text: A security analyst at an organization is reviewing vulnerability reports from a newly deployed vulnerability management platform. The organization is not receiving information about devices that rarely connect to the network. Which of the following will the analyst most likely do to obtain vulnerability information about these devices?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Cloud-based agents can provide continuous monitoring and vulnerability assessment regardless of the device's connection status to the organization's network. These agents can collect and report vulnerability information even when devices are not regularly connected to the local network. 

MDM solutions primarily focuses on managing and securing mobile devices. Typically work well for devices that are actively managed and regularly communicate with the organization's network.

Selected Answer: B
ChatGPT
To obtain vulnerability information about devices that rarely connect to the network, the security analyst should consider cloud-based agents (option B).

Cloud-based agents can periodically communicate with the central vulnerability management platform regardless of whether the devices are connected to the corporate network. These agents can provide valuable data, such as vulnerability assessments and security updates, for devices that are off-network or infrequently connected.

Options A, C, and D are related to mobile device management (MDM) and network access control (NAC), which may not be as effective for devices that are rarely connected to the network. Cloud-based agents provide a more flexible and continuous monitoring approach in such cases.

Selected Answer: B
To obtain vulnerability information about devices that rarely connect to the network, organizations can use cloud-based agents or solutions. Cloud-based agents are lightweight software agents that can be installed on devices and are capable of periodically connecting to cloud-based vulnerability management platforms. These agents collect and report vulnerability data even when the devices are not frequently connected to the corporate network. This approach ensures that all devices, including those with sporadic network connectivity, can be included in vulnerability assessment and management processes.
